dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, we often talk about, like, the global order and stuff, but this article really hits home, uh, how much things have changed. It starts by saying that Fukuyama's "end of history" idea, you know, seems almost *quaint* now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, we often talk about, like, the global order and stuff, but this article really hits home, uh, how much things have changed. It starts by saying that Fukuyama's end of history idea, you know, seems almost quaint now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, as we face a retreat from the rules-based, liberal global order, with autocratic rulers and demagogues leading countries that contain well over half the worlds population, Fukuyamas idea seems quaint and naive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally. And it points out that, for the last forty years, that whole worldview really propped up this idea of neoliberalism, right? Like, unfettered markets leading to shared prosperity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally. And it points out that, for the last forty years, that whole worldview really propped up this idea of neoliberalism, right? Like, unfettered markets leading to shared prosperity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But it reinforced the neoliberal economic doctrine that has prevailed for the last 40 years. The credibility of neoliberalisms faith in unfettered markets as the surest road to shared prosperity is on life-support these days.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! But, um, that belief system? The article says it's basically on life support these days. And, well, it probably *should* be.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But, um, that belief system? The article says it's basically on life support these days. And, well, it probably should be.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The credibility of neoliberalisms faith in unfettered markets as the surest road to shared prosperity is on life-support these days. And well it should be.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And it's no coincidence, like, that the waning of confidence in neoliberalism and democracy are happening at the same time. This article argues that neoliberalism actually *undermined* democracy for decades.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's no coincidence, like, that the waning of confidence in neoliberalism and democracy are happening at the same time. This article argues that neoliberalism actually undermined democracy for decades.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The simultaneous waning of confidence in neoliberalism and in democracy is no coincidence or mere correlation. Neoliberalism has undermined democracy for 40 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty stark. Think about, uh, capital-market liberalization. They give this example: if a presidential candidate in an emerging market didn't play ball with Wall Street, the banks would just pull their money out. Voters were then forced to choose.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty stark. Think about, uh, capital-market liberalization. They give this example: if a presidential candidate in an emerging market didn't play ball with Wall Street, the banks would just pull their money out. Voters were then forced to choose.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The effects of capital-market liberalization were particularly odious: If a leading presidential candidate in an emerging market lost favor with Wall Street, the banks would pull their money out of the country. Voters then faced a stark choice: Give in to Wall Street or face a severe financial crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Right? So Wall Street basically had more power than the country's citizens! And even in rich countries, we were told, "Oh, you can't have decent wages or social protections because you'll lose competitiveness."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? So Wall Street basically had more power than the country's citizens! And even in rich countries, we were told, Oh, you can't have decent wages or social protections because you'll lose competitiveness.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It was as if Wall Street had more political power than the countrys citizens. Even in rich countries, ordinary citizens were told, You cant pursue the policies you want whether adequate social protection, decent wages, progressive taxation, or a well-regulated financial system because the country will lose competitiveness, jobs will disappear, and you will suffer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild. And all this time, the elites were promising that these policies would lead to faster growth, and that the benefits would, uh, 'trickle down' to everyone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild. And all this time, the elites were promising that these policies would lead to faster growth, and that the benefits would, uh, trickle down to everyone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In rich and poor countries alike, elites promised that neoliberal policies would lead to faster economic growth, and that the benefits would trickle down so that everyone, including the poorest, would be better off.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Trickle down! Oh, man. Forty years later, the numbers are in, and that absolutely did *not* happen. Growth slowed, and the fruits of that growth went overwhelmingly to, like, a very few at the very top.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Trickle down! Oh, man. Forty years later, the numbers are in, and that absolutely did not happen. Growth slowed, and the fruits of that growth went overwhelmingly to, like, a very few at the very top.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Well, after 40 years, the numbers are in: growth has slowed, and the fruits of that growth went overwhelmingly to a very few at the top.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Wages stagnated, stock market soared, and wealth just flowed *up*. People felt totally conned.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Wages stagnated, stock market soared, and wealth just flowed up. People felt totally conned.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As wages stagnated and the stock market soared, income and wealth flowed up, rather than trickling down. ... Ordinary citizens felt like they had been sold a bill of goods. They were right to feel conned.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And that's why we're seeing all this distrust now, right? Distrust of the elites, of the economic science they claimed this was based on, and, um, of the whole political system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that's why we're seeing all this distrust now, right? Distrust of the elites, of the economic science they claimed this was based on, and, um, of the whole political system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are now experiencing the political consequences of this grand deception: distrust of the elites, of the economic science on which neoliberalism was based, and of the money-corrupted political system that made it all possible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah. And it's interesting, the article says that despite its name, the era of neoliberalism was actually "far from liberal." It imposed, like, an intellectual orthodoxy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah. And it's interesting, the article says that despite its name, the era of neoliberalism was actually far from liberal. It imposed, like, an intellectual orthodoxy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The reality is that, despite its name, the era of neoliberalism was far from liberal. It imposed an intellectual orthodoxy whose guardians were utterly intolerant of dissent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. They treated economists with, uh, different views as "heretics." It wasn't about open debate at all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. They treated economists with, uh, different views as heretics. It wasn't about open debate at all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Economists with heterodox views were treated as heretics to be shunned, or at best shunted off to a few isolated institutions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And remember the 2008 financial crisis? They just called it a "500-year flood," a freak occurrence that their models couldn't predict.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And remember the two thousand eight financial crisis? They just called it a five hundred-year flood, a freak occurrence that their models couldn't predict.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the impossible happened, it was treated as if it were a 500-year flood a freak occurrence that no model could have predicted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which is just, like, a refusal to admit that their belief in self-regulating markets and deregulation actually *caused* the crisis!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is just, like, a refusal to admit that their belief in self-regulating markets and deregulation actually caused the crisis!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even today, advocates of these theories refuse to accept that their belief in self-regulating markets and their dismissal of externalities as either nonexistent or unimportant led to the deregulation that was pivotal in fueling the crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. And if the 2008 crisis didn't wake us up, the climate crisis, um, really should. Neoliberalism, it says, could literally bring an end to our civilization.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. And if the two thousand eight crisis didn't wake us up, the climate crisis, um, really should. Neoliberalism, it says, could literally bring an end to our civilization.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the 2008 financial crisis failed to make us realize that unfettered markets dont work, the climate crisis certainly should: neoliberalism will literally bring an end to our civilization.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what's the solution then? Just throw everything out?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what's the solution then? Just throw everything out?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article calls for a "rebirth of history," you know? Revitalizing the Enlightenment values of freedom, respect for knowledge, and democracy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article calls for a rebirth of history, you know? Revitalizing the Enlightenment values of freedom, respect for knowledge, and democracy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The only way forward, the only way to save our planet and our civilization, is a rebirth of history. We must revitalize the Enlightenment and recommit to honoring its values of freedom, respect for knowledge, and democracy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's a huge, um, undertaking. But it sounds like a necessary one if we want to save our planet, and, like, our civilization, as they put it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a huge, um, undertaking. But it sounds like a necessary one if we want to save our planet, and, like, our civilization, as they put it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The only way forward, the only way to save our planet and our civilization, is a rebirth of history.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Couldn't agree more. It's a pretty powerful message.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Couldn't agree more. It's a pretty powerful message.
